content.description: Climbs the left side of the face on nice holds. Best done at low tide!
content.location: This is on the Lamprey Boulder which is down at the tide line. Look for the huge block sitting on the side of the river.

content.description: Sit start the right end of the overhang at the sloping arete. Pull to a good hold at the lip and mantle.
content.location: This climbs the arete that forms the left edge of an obvious groove.

content.description: Climb the right side of the tall face. Be prepared, you may have an audience from across the river.  Best done at low tide.
content.location: This is on the Lamprey Boulder which is down at the tide line. Look for the huge block sitting on the side of the river.

content.description: Climbs the right side of the slab. Balance grab the lip and mantle.
Climbs the crack up the middle of the tall face. Best done at low tide.
content.location: This is on the Lamprey Boulder which is down at the tide line. Look for the huge block sitting on the side of the river.

content.description: Sit start on the far left side of the boulder so that the river is to your back. Traverse right on small rails and side pulls to gain sloper(avoid bumping into the tree), keep traversing around buldge and onto face climb on other side topping out on right side of highest part of boulder. Nice little gem
Climb the middle of the short face on tiny crimps.
content.location: This is on the downhill side of a small boulder located just off the right side of the hiking trail as your heading to the Heron Point Boulder.

content.description: Sit start the small overhang at ok crimps. Pull up and right to the sidepull then better holds up top.
content.location: Look for a blunt arete left of a tree.

content.description: Climb the face left of the crack starting at the low jug.
content.location: Look for the two big grooves/cracks on the back side of the boulder. This climbs the face left of the left hand crack.

content.description: Sit start in the small pit left of the tree at the crimps. Pull to a good edge then grab jugs over the lip. Mantle onto the top.
content.location: On the Heron Point Boulder. This is the first feature you see when you approach along the hiking trail. Look for a pit at the base of the boulder left of the big tree.

content.description: Sit start at the low jug. Pull to the good edge and pocket then up through ok holds over the lip onto the top.
content.location: Starts in the overhang to the right of the big tree.

content.description: Climb the face between the two cracks utilizing the two aretes.
content.location: Look for the two cracks/grooves on the back side of the boulder. This climbs the face between the two grooves.

content.description: Climb the left side of the slab past a left-facing sidepull to the lip and mantle.
content.location: On the blank, slightly less-than-vertical wall.

content.description: A bit of a one-move-wonder. Sit start at the horizontal rail. Pull to the jug rail at the lip and mantle.
content.location: This climbs just left of the tree.

content.description:
Start down on the left corner of the boulder (side facing the river) where the crack begins. Traverse the crack using your heels well before topping out on the right side.  

  Fun little problem, not sure if it's been done before.
content.location: This boulder sits about halfway down the slope between the hiking trail and the riverside Lamprey Boulder. This climb is on the downhill face of the boulder.

content.description: An awesome little park right across from downtown Newmarket. The woods contain 2 large glacial erratics, and many smaller boulders. The park is cleared out from heavy traffic, but some big pine trees keep it nice and shady. Make sure you pick your way down to the river to check out the big boulder.
